org.qbroker.cluster

Class PacketNode

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.qbroker.cluster.PacketNode
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable, ClusterNode

    public class PacketNode
extends java.lang.Object
implements ClusterNode, java.lang.Runnable
    PacketNode is a cluster node of a MulticastGroup. The cluster contains a number of PacketNodes communicating with each other via DatagramPackets. One of the nodes is the manager that supervises the entire group or cluster. The rest of nodes are workers reporting to the manager and monitoring its behavior closely. In case that the manager quits or any node misses certain number of heartbeats from the manager, the rest of the workers will elect a new manager and resume to work. Any new node can join the group anytime as long as there is a room available in the group. Any worker can leave the group anytime. If the last node leaves the group, the cluster goes down.

    PacketNode also supports the extra path for communications between nodes if ExtraReceiver is defined. With ExtraReceiver, each outgoing packet will be duplicated on its content. Then it will be sent out via the extra communication path. Currently, ExtraReceiver only supports two of the schemes, comm or udp. In case of comm, an RS232 connection is required. It means the cluster size will be limited to 2. In case of udp, it requires a separate subnet as the secondary communication path. Also the URI of ExtraReceiver must be different from the primary one. Due to the limit on the udp IP bindings, each machine can only host one node at most. Either way, it increases the reliability and the redundancy of the cluster.

    PacketNode is supposed to run at backgroud. It is designed to be a black automaton box. It will automatically maitain the state of the cluster. But if the escalation outLink is specified at startup, it will also send the state information and relay the data. The application on the node can intercept the events from the node and send data to any other nodes via the API of relay().

    A PacketNode may be in one of the following states:
    NODE_NEW: just starting up, not joining the cluster yet
    NODE_RUNNING: joined in the cluster and running OK
    NODE_STANDBY: joined in the cluster but still in transient state
    NODE_TIMEOUT: missed a fixed number of heartbeats from the node
    NODE_DOWN: no longer active

    Author:
    yannanlu@yahoo.com
